chief_complaint: Painless, non-healing large ulcer on her left leg.
history_of_present_illness: A 14-year-old girl from the Solomon Islands reported a painless, non-healing large ulcer of her left leg that began 1 month earlier.
exposure_and_epidemiology: Patient is from the Solomon Islands, an area highly endemic for yaws. Yaws is associated with overcrowding and poor hygiene.
physical_exam: Large crusted lesion (approximately 3 cm diameter) on the left lower leg. A smaller, similar satellite lesion was noted lower down the leg. No regional lymphadenopathy or evidence of any other skin or bone lesions.
labs_and_diagnostics: Rapid plasma reagin (RPR) test positive at a titre of 1:64 (Normal â€“ Negative).
differential_diagnosis: Yaws, Haemophilus ducreyi infection, pyoderma, tropical ulcer, cutaneous diphtheria, Aeromonas hydrophila infection.
management_and_clinical_course: Initially treated with a single intramuscular (IM) dose of benzathine benzylpenicillin. The skin lesion resolved over the next 10 days. Twelve months later, the patient presented with a similar ulcer on the right leg. A repeat RPR test was positive at a titre of 1:8. This was considered a cure for the initial infection due to a greater than four-fold fall in the RPR titre, and the new ulcer was interpreted to be of a different etiology.
final_diagnosis: Yaws (caused by Treponema pallidum subspecies pertenue).
